statement:
Let $f$ be an holomorphic function with an essential singularity at
$w\in \mathbb{C}$. Then there is a number $z_0\in \mathbb{C}$ such that
the image of any neighborhood of $w$ by $f$ contains
$\mathbb{C}-\{z_0\}$. In other words, $f$ assumes every complex value,
with the possible exception of $z_0$, in any neighborhood of $w$.

*Remark.* Little Picard theorem follows as a corollary: Given a
nonconstant entire function $f$, if it is a polynomial, it assumes every
value in $\mathbb{C}$ as a consequence of the fundamental theorem of
algebra. If $f$ is not a polynomial, then $g(z)=f(1/z)$ has an essential
singularity at $0$; Picard’s theorem implies that $g$ (and thus $f$)
assumes every complex value, with one possible exception.
